title: George Bates (English footballer)
text:
George Reginald Bates (21 November 1923January 1995) was an English <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who played <a href="outside%20forward">on the wing</a> for <a href="Darlington%20F.C.">Darlington</a> in the <a href="English%20Football%20League">Football League</a>. He was on the books of <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday">Sheffield Wednesday</a> and <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a> without representing either in the League, and played <a href="non-league%20football">non-league football</a> for <a href="Gainsborough%20Trinity%20F.C.">Gainsborough Trinity</a>.
Life and career.
Bates was born in <a href="Sheffield">Sheffield</a> in 1923, the son of Reginald and Alice Bates. At the time of the <a href="1939%20Register">1939 Register</a>, the family were living in Cammell Road, Sheffield; Bates was working as an assistant in a grocer's shop and his father was a locomotive driver.
Bates played football for the <a href="works%20team">works team</a> of Sheffield-based <a href="crankshaft">crankshaft</a> manufacturer Ambrose Shardlow before joining <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday">Sheffield Wednesday</a> in March 1945. He made nine appearances and scored once in the wartime leagues during what remained of the 1944–45 season, but played no first-team football in 1945–46. He then signed for <a href="Darlington%20F.C.">Darlington</a>, and appeared in three of the first four <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20North">Third Division North</a> matches of the <a href="1946%E2%80%9347%20Football%20League">1946–47 Football League</a> season.
After trials with another Third Division North club, <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a>, during which he appeared in the <a href="Midland%20Football%20League%20%281889%29">Midland League</a> for their reserve teamaccording to the "<a href="Lincolnshire%20Echo">Lincolnshire Echo</a>", he "accomplished little, apart from a left foot drive that all but produced an early goal" and with <a href="Yorkshire%20Football%20League">Yorkshire League</a> club <a href="Goole%20Town%20F.C.">Goole Town</a>, Bates signed for <a href="Gainsborough%20Trinity">Gainsborough Trinity</a>, with whom he spent the next three seasons. He played regularly for their Midland League side for the first two years, but towards the end of the third he was more often with the reserve team in the Yorkshire League. In 1950, he signed for <a href="Boston%20United%20F.C.">Boston United</a>, but never played first-team football for them.
Bates died in Sheffield in 1995 at the age of 71.
